Either they need to be more discriminant in their product selection, or they need more careful shipping and handling.

Label: Neutral
Content: I'm not sure why this taste so different from the Chef Boyardee regular Ravioli, but it taste more bland. It's still a cheap snack to have around though.

Label: Neutral
Content: cheap if you have nothing else to eat. But if you have a sensitive stomach this slop is not for you.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Leave out the saturated Fats Please!
Content: I liked raviolis as a kid and thought I would enjoy the childhood flavors again. Chef Boyardee Raviolis taste pretty good just like I remember. Really filling too! Usually when a product is really filling I know it has lots of fat and these raviolis were no exception. 3.5 grams of saturate fat! I'm not accustom to eating that much fat and they made we feel a little nauseous shortly after eating them. Lighten it up Chef Boyardee!

Label: Neutral
Content: I eat Kippers all the time. I have found that there is no correlation between price and quality. These pretend to be from local fisherman in Maine.I am from Maine, I could not find this company until I went to Google Maps. These guys are inland, and buying this stuff from Canada and Europe. No problem with that but please do not BS us. There kippers are only OK. I like King Oscar better, and Polar after that. And both those are cheaper. I do like that they have a goodly sized portion, but I can eat two King Oscars for less than one of theirs. Just saying.

Label: Neutral
Summary: They're fine, but not a quantum leap from what I can get in a supermarket.
Content:
Kippers are really fishy fish that are great if you love fish but can cause others (like wives) to run screaming out of the house. I purchased these due to the other reviews, and because at the time the price for 12 6.7 oz cans compared very well to the price of 24 3 oz little cans at my local supermarket.

However, the overall kipper experience wasn't really much different from the stuff I bought off the store shelves locally. What I got what just what I expected, a can of soggy fishy tasting fish that gives me a lot of protien and if served with the right bread or cracker and some spreadable chive and onion cheese is quite a healthy snack if I'm hungry enough to want to eat it.

Oh yeah, the pull tabs break off really easy on these, so even though you can't wait to dive into these cans of kippers, take it slow when you open them or you'll be digging around for your can opener.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Not as good as buying from the store
Content: I love these crackers, but I just received my first subscription shipment for these and I will probably not buy them again. There are an above average number of smashed crackers and they taste somewhat stale even though the expiration date is next year.

Label: Neutral
Content:
While both of the flavors (sharp cheddar & parmesan) are individually savory, the combined flavors were not great. The first box I opened had a great number of broken and crumbled crackers, which resulted in the flavorings melding together. In addition, the crackers had much more moisture than expected. This moisture allowed the flavorings to mix further.

The other three boxes were better - crisper and not as many broken crackers. This allowed me to separate the crackers by flavor, which sort of defeated the "Duoz" concept.

I had higher expectations and definitely would not have these again.

Label: Neutral
Content:
These came and the crackers were all together in one container.
I thought the difference flavor crackers would have been in their
own container. The flavors were okay, but hard to tell what the
flavor really was. Very salty.

Label: Neutral
Content: We love the taste of the cookies/meringues and the price was better than at the store but many of the cookies were crushed which made them messy.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Let me say first that these aren't a bad snack food. They have the all the sweetness and flavor you're looking for in a meringue cookie. The problem comes in the fact that they don't "finish" well. That is, they tend to leave a gummy residue on the molars, which is easily removed by the tongue but still annoying. It does become an issue if you eat an actual "serving size" as you end up constantly removing that residue.

I won't be ordering again.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Tasty, but gummy at end. Good low cal alternative.
Content: The taste very similar to the original vanilla, which I ordered just a little while ago. The do have that nice crunchy texture to start, but then end up gummy and sticks to your teeth. Not bad if you have a craving for them, but you will want to brush your teeth and floss after eating them and for some people they will hate the clingy fee. It's not really a problem for those who eat them by putting them in their mouth and letting them dissolve, more for those who munch on them.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Great nutritional profile, tastes good with orange tea
Content:
These are made with mostly air and egg white and have a fantastic nutritional profile for bodybuilders and people losing weight or maintaining a weight loss. I've lost 160 lbs through diet and exercise and like the reviewer who had surgery, I don't want to eat the amount of sugar found in normal meringues. The fact there's a reasonable amount of protein in there is a bonus.

With the holidays coming up I appreciate having a treat to bring to parties and dinners that I can both share AND eat, while staying within my daily nutritional target.

I can find the chocolate ones in a grocery store 40 min from my home, but the vanilla ones nowhere. This price beats the other online offers and you only have to buy 6 containers at a time.

The chocolate meringues taste better by themselves than the vanilla, but paired with TAZO Wild Sweet Orange Herbal Infusion Tea, Caffeine Free, 20-Count Tea Bags (Pack of 6), the vanilla meringues are fantastic. I bet they'd be good with other citrus teas as well.

For example, Numi Tea Dry Desert Lime Herbal Tessan, Tea Bags, 18-Count Boxes (Pack of 6) or Bigelow I Love Lemon Herbal Tea, 20-Count Boxes (Pack of 6).

I wish they made other sugar free flavors, such as mint or cinnamon.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Grossly overpriced little bags of cookies. I was under the impression this was 6 packs of 6 bags each. But I only got one measly little 6x1oz package. The per ounce price noted is a fraud.

....
But, Amazon did the right thing and offered me a refund of 5/6 of what I paid. Still, this item seem to be unclear with regard to how many you are actually getting.

Label: Neutral
Summary: blue buffalo dry food for puppies
Content: Nutritious, but my puppies did not like the flavor. I purchased a second bag hoping they would learn to like it, but they did not.

Label: Neutral
Content:
If you are used to buying the Piggy Twists that are about the size of fat cigars, these are not them. These come 20 to a pack, but the individual twist is about as wide as a regular drinking straw, and 2/3 as long. If you have a very small (as in toy breed) dog, they are probably great. I have two dogs between 50-60 lbs., and these are barely worth pulling out of the bag.

UPDATE: After using all the piggy twists (because I'd bought them), we are now used to this size and actually prefer them to the big cigar-like ones because they don't make such a mess. I still think they are made for tiny dogs, but they will keep a 50-60 lb dog occupied for a while, too. Just realize what size you are getting with this purchase, because the product picture does not make it clear.

Label: Neutral
Content: I thought we were getting the enormous bundle for the price I paid, which I thought was a deal. Instead it turned out to be a small pack of the twists. Could have gotten these in person for the same amount elsewhere.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Great supplemental food, BUT...

READ THE LABEL: "Fancy Feast Appetizers are intended for SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING ONLY. This product may be fed daily along with a complete and balanced cat food diet."

DO NOT FEED this as only food source for your cat. These DO NOT contain a very necessary ingredient, TAURINE. Feeding processed/canned or even home-cooked meats and fish to cats requires Taurine as the cooking process destroys Taurine. Lack of Taurine is known to cause eye and heart problems in cats. . Do some research on Taurine! It's in all cat food, by law. I don't know how Fancy Feast got away with omitting it. They assume all cat owners read labels....so not true. . Do some research on Taurine! It's in all cat food, by law. I don't know how Fancy Feast got away with omitting it. They assume all cat owners read labels....so not true.

I love cats so here to give a head's up to those who intend to use this as the main source of their cat's diet...

Label: Neutral
Content:
Just put in to try to give a fall boost for SPRING GROWTH. Some crappy soil needs a boost, so trying to help out a little now, in the MN Fall...

***Still not sure - the grass is very happy where the spike went in the ground - lots of new growth on the pines - and others, but is that becuase of the extremely wet spring thus far in MN?? Didn't hurt - I know that for sure!

fyi, I used a 2x2 stake and pounded it into the ground to create a hole first, then dropped the spike into that. Otherwise, the spike gets pulverized trying to drive it in by itself, with that silly little plastic cap on it.

Label: Neutral
Content:
My dog is a finicky eater and in the stores when I bought the packets that come 4 flavors to a box, my dog loved the chicken and the turkey but none of the other flavors so buying just one box full of the flavor he liked seemed perfect. However, I had not fully read the ingredients before making the purchase. The good part is that it is all meat with no grains and my dog seems to have an allergy to many things which makes him finicky. BUT it has onion powder and garlic powder. Now these may make it taste better and the dog seems to enjoy but it also causes damage to his already weakened liver. Had I read the ingredients fully before even as finicky eater I would not have purchased because I know onion in any form is very dangerous to little dogs. Garlic not much better but worse for one with weakened liver already. So after having a package or two of his favs, he got sicker and has gastritis terrible.. had to go to vet and is still recovering so won't be using the rest of the packages.

Read full ingredients before giving anything to your little guy and be sure he's able to digest these products.

Now I just buy ground turkey and ground chicken, or whole, cook it up myself and give it to my little guy making certain there is nothing in the food that can cause him severe illness.

Label: Neutral
Content: We've tried several base mixes for our dogs' raw diet, and this one was one of the easiest to work with--the preparation steps couldn't be easier, and the wait time before serving is the shortest I've encountered yet. I also liked the packaging; it was very easy to store and didn't take up much space. However, our dogs weren't crazy about its smell and taste. It smells overwhelmingly like alfalfa and fruit, even after we mixed in the meat and some chicken broth to cut the odor. One of our dogs flat out refused to eat it. The other picked around the mixture or spit it out as he was eating his meat. I wanted to like this product, but the other flavors that had meat included (and less alfalfa) seemed much more palatable to our pups.

Label: Neutral
Content: I give this 3 stars because it wasn't unpleasant coffee.  It just didn't taste like anything.  It reminded me of hot water with those Folgers coffee bags dunked in it for a little bit.  I don't like too strong a coffee but this was way underpowered for coffee.  I enjoy the bolder coffees, too, such as Coffee People Organic Bold and Dark Magic.  I would not buy Nantucket again.

Label: Neutral
Content: I ordered the Green Mountain Coffee Nantucket Blend which I like as a smooth medium roast morning coffee.  I received the Green Mountain Breakfast Blend which is too mild for my liking.  Three stars for the coffee received. I won't order again from the Amazon marketing partner that sold it.

Label: Neutral
Content: Does anyone know if K-Cups can be recycled?  I cannot seem to find out.  I would be much more likely to purchase a coffee machine that uses K-Cups if I knew the cups could be recycled.

Label: Neutral
Content: I had many a k-cup but at 1.29 a piece. I'll just take my refill cup to the store and let someone else make me a cup. I have bought k cups on sale for as little as .54 a piece. Green mountain is one of the better coffees but lets be realistic with the price huh.

Label: Neutral
Content: There ok have gone way up in price. Now that I have tried the Dunkin Donuts k-cups not sure if I will be going back to green mountain.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Nice coffee to start the day
Content:
I enjoy starting the day with a cup of coffee. Once upon a time, I just used instant. Some were decent quality; some weren't. Then, I tried Mr. Coffee. Sorry, not my cuppa! Back to instant. Maxwell House had some nice instant.

But my family wanted a Keurig coffee maker, so--for the holidays this year--I bought one. The coffee that came with it was a Newman's Own blend. Pretty bold and tasty (better than instant and quite a bit better than my memory of Mr. Coffee). I recently ordered this through Amazon. It is not quite as bold as the Newman's Own k-cup coffee. But it does have a smooth taste that starts the day off nicely. So, I have encountered two good coffees for the Keurig coffee maker!

Label: Neutral
Content:
Ordered this product without reading what i was getting ... dumb on my part.
My wife loves Nantucket Blend. I mistakenly thought this was for 2 boxes of 24 k-cups because of the price.
Much cheaper to pick this great product up at Kohls or Bed Bath and Beyond if you have access to them.

Label: Neutral
Content: A matter of taste, I prefer darker, richer roasts. This one is lighter on the coffee aroma and flavor and heavy on the acidity. A true "medium" coffee, I would say.

Label: Neutral
Content: I have to say I was expecting a lot. I had been giving my dog Greenies but they were becoming outrageously priced. I thought I'd try these ones and admittedly, my dog loves them. The only problem is the treats stink. As in they smell, bad. I was hoping with a name like "Freshies" they would help with bad breath but so far they just seem to mask whatever he'd eaten before them. Don't get me wrong, they don't smell totally awful, I just had expectations of "fresh" not chicken smell.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Pretty Good Tasting But Too High in Calories, Fat and Carbs For Me To Buy!
Content: Let me start off by saying that I am not a big fan of granola bars but I enjoyed the big nut taste and peanut butter flavor in the Planters Big Nut Bar. On a taste basis alone, I'd give this product a 4-star rating. The only negative I had is that after eating it I was left with a quite dry taste in my mouth and had to drink a lot of water to get rid of it. If I wasn't a person who is trying to carefully watch my intake of calories, fat and carbs I'd be looking to eat Planters Big Nut Bar on a regular basis when I wanted a good tasting, high protein snack. However, given that each 1.62 oz. bar contains 220 calories (110 from fat), 13 grams total fat and 22 grams of carbs, I'd only give a 2-star rating to the nutritional qualities of this product; thus, resulting in my overall rating of 3 stars. While I liked the taste of the Big Nut Bar, the product's amount of calories, fat and carbs will prevent me from being a buyer on anything more than a very occasional basis. However, if you are not carefully watching these nutritional factors and you want a good tasting, high protein snack bar, than I think you will find that the Big Nut Bar will satisfy your needs.

Label: Neutral
Content:
I opened my Big Nut Bar to see what appeared to be a rice krispies treat coated at the bottom with peanut butter.

After taking my first bite, I realized that the texture was far chewier then a rice krispies. This wasn't surprising, as dried peanuts are a bit tougher then rice krispies.

All in all, I thought that the peanut bar was pretty tasty. However, it was a little to chewy for my taste. This should be avoided by all people who wear dentures, as one bite may take your teeth right off.

Label: Neutral
Content: These bars start out sweet when you first bite into them - almost like you're having a peanut butter sandwich. But then they leave a bitter after taste. On the plus side, it's really very nutty! But that bitter after taste is the main the reason why I don't like this product. And if that matters to you, I wouldn't buy this.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Not Nutty Enough For A Peanut Nut
Content:
The binder ingredient in this large snack bar is crisped rice so it tastes like a "Rice Crispy Treat" with peanuts inside. The crispy rice forms the dominant texture of the bar. An occasional peanut is not enough to give the rich meaty crunch of a handful of roast peanuts which I was expecting from the picture on the box. The dominant flavor comes from the coating of sweet peanut butter on the bottom of the bar. Because the sweetening is corn syrup, the bar is sweet but the flavor is not remarkable or distinctive. Certainly the "Double Peanut" marketing implies one thing, but I find the bar disappointing and the peanut butter undercoat is messy in warm weather.

However, there are worse snacks! Each bar offers 100% of vitamin E, no cholesterol and no trans fats. There's a reasonable amount of sodium and 7 grams of protein per bar. A decent energy snack and a quick pick-me-up when the blood sugar is running low.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Okay for a quick peanuty snack, but...
Content:
If you're craving a handy peanuty snack, then this will likely suit your tastes. However, I found it a bit too sweet for the 'salty' I was looking for.

While the package highlights 7gms of protein, don't think this is 'lean' protein. With 13gms of fat per bar, you're packing away 20% of your RDA. I was surprised at other contents as well.

Pleasantly:
Sodium is 160gms (7%)
Carbs 22gms (12%)
Fiber 3g (12%)

I expected all these numbers to be higher, so this swayed favor with me.

Ultimately, I'm not keen on the inclusion of corn syrup (though not hydrogenated) as an ingredient, but was happy that most of the rest of the listed ingredients were 'natural' in that I recognized the names. However, I'd hardly call this a 'granola' bar, as is listed on the packaging. The 'granola' element is barely noticeable between the nuts and the peanut butter.

I wouldn't plan on one a day to supplement my diet, but as an occasional quick and peanuty treat, it's not bad.

My 3 year-old 'picky eater' niece enjoyed it too :)

Label: Neutral
Summary: Good taste but lacks nutritional value
Content: Length:: 1:24 Mins

Label: Neutral
Content:
These are the second distinctly nut-flavored meal or snack bars I've ever tried, but I didn't enjoy them as much as I did the Planters Big Nut Bars, Roasted Triple Nut, 8.1-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 10) because it turned out that "Double Peanut" in this case meant peanuts and peanut butter, which I don't usually care for. Anyway, I won't be ordering anymore because of a somewhat uncommon (and thus not specifically warning labeled about) food allergy.

I'm extremely allergic to Canola Oil, also known as Rapeseed Oil, which in me produces severe hives and swellings in the throat. Fortunately, my allergic threshold is relatively high so that small amounts usually produce no reaction. However, caution induces me to check labels and avoid it whenever I can; labels reading "may contain one or more of the following vegetable oils:" are the bane of my existence, asking me the question, "Do I feel lucky?"

Unfortunately, near the end of the ingredient list, near the end of the sub-list for granola is my old nemesis Canola Oil. Consuming no more than a single bar per day and that not on consecutive days spared me any allergic reaction, but I will take no further chances when I am NOT obliged to write a review.

Label: Neutral
Content:
These Planters Big Nut Bars are just so-so. They're not sweet enough to be super-yummy, and not boring enough to be just normal peanuts. They're right in between.

Personally, I prefer the sweeter taste of some of the other bars on the market such as the Nature Valley line.

The size of these bars is pretty big, though, and certainly bigger than their competitors. Too big? I wouldn't say that.

Size aside, they could have fit 5 extra bars in the packaging if they just turned them a different direction. Odd.

One complaint: the wrapping around the bars is difficult to open without: 1) tearing it into shreds, and 2) getting peanut butter all over your fingers. I don't seem to have this problem with other bars of a similar nature.

And as other reviewers have noted, these are far from being a "healthy snack"... unless your alternative is a Pop Tart.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Planter's Big Nut Bars are basically bars of peanuts, sugar, granola, and crispy rice with a layer of peanut butter on the bottom. They're very chewy and pretty good, but I can only handle half a bar at a time.

These "healthy" snacks are pretty high in calories, and I sometimes found them to be too sweet. I have a serious sweet tooth, but for some reason I couldn't really take all the sugar in these bars. I don't know if it's because Planters wants me to think that this is a healthy alternative to granola bars, and so my mind was rejecting the sugary sweetness, but I definitely could not finish a full bar in one sitting.

I'm kind of impartial to the Big Nut Bars; it's definitely something that I won't go out of my way to get at the grocery store, but if it's on sale I would probably pick up a box.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Taste wise, These are great. Nutrition wise, That's where this falls shorts. When I Think "Granola Bar" Which these are falsely labeled as, I think of something that isn't an almost exact equivalent of a 2 pack of Reese's Peanut Butter Cups, which nutrition wise, these are, give or take 10 calories.

It's pretty much just a bar of peanuts with Corn Syrup and peanut butter. I'd say Stick with Planters Original Peanut Bar or Snickers Munch or just plain Peanut Brittle. Those pack more of a great Crunch.

Tasty Treat, which is why it gets 3 stars But Labeling it as a Granola bar - False advertising.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Tasty, but high in fat and calories
Content:
I really like the taste of these -- but that taste comes at the price of a bar that is very high in fat, sugar, and calories. Each bar contains 220 calories, 110 of which come from fat, and each one also has 12 grams of sugar, which is very high for a bar this size.

Also, when my husband tried these, he wasn't too keen on the taste. When I asked for his opinion on them, he just said that they were "Meh."

Bottom line? These are tasty, but certainly should be eaten in moderation. Since I'm a health nut, I won't be buying these again.

Label: Neutral
Content: I actually prefer the Triple Nut version of this bar better despite the fact that I really like peanuts.  I think it is just a little bit too much like a candy bar for me to actually want to eat it too often and when I had one in my pocket for a few hours it got really messy because the peanut butter melted and got all over the inside of the wrapper and made the bar sticky and not that attractive looking, in fact it was a hot day when these were delivered so they were already pretty messed up before I even got them.  They do taste pretty good, so if you like things sweet, like peanuts and peanut butter and don't mind that they can get kinda messy, you would like this bar.

Label: Neutral
Content: I would never consider this a healthy option, but it tastes pretty good. I'm not a huge fan of peanuts and sugar since I prefer the peanuts and salty combination, so this snack is too sweet for me. And I should say that it's very dense and filling. I could barely finish my whole bar and finishing food is not normally a problem I have!

Label: Neutral
Content:
FLAVOR
As everyone else agrees, this is pretty tasty. It is full of delicious nutty flavor. But, it barely has a hint of granola (in my opinion). Also, it is very filling. I only ate half of the first bar I tried because I was full thanks to all the nuts. Nuts, in moderation, are a good source of good fats.

NUTRITIONAL INFO
The bar is indeed big; about 30% bigger than regular granola bars. This 46 gram bar has 220 calories, no trans fats, 3 grams of saturated fats, 160 mg of sodium, 22 g of carbohydrates, 3 grams of fiber, 12 grams of sugar, 7 grams of protein, a negligible amounts of calcium and iron, 100% of you Vitamin E daily value and 10% of your daily value of Phosphorous. It has no other vitamins. It also has 3.5 grams of polyunsaturated fats and 6 grams of monosaturated fats.

All these fats are not unhealthy. As I mentioned before, nuts are a good source of healthy fats. But, this bar may just a be too big for a regular snack.

COMPARISON WITH A SIMILAR BAR
A single Planters bar is 220 calories, almost as much as a Clif Bar (240 calories), but not as healthy. Why? The Planters bar has 110 calories from fat which equals to 13 grams of fat, 20% of your daily value. It also has 3 grams of saturated fats, which is not the best heart healthy choice. Whereas a Clif Bar has 7 grams of fat, 11 % of your daily value and 1.5 grams of saturated fats.

Also, Clif bars are made with organic ingredients. Two of the first three ingredients of a Planters bar are: sugar and corn syrup. Doctors, nutritionists, exercise and health experts all tell you to avoid or reduce food items that have sugar and corn syrup in the first five listed ingredients.

It also has artificial flavors AND more sugar (brown sugar, dextrin, fructose, evaporated cane juice, etc.). Yes, I know that Clif bars have 21 grams of sugar, but at least they are natural and organic based. Moreover, the Clif bar is full of vitamins and minerals.

Further, the Clif bar is recommended for people doing high intensity sports or requiring sustained energy: hiking, rock climbing, or any other sports. This Planters bar being advertised as a snack.

BOTTOM LINE
Is such a big bar truly necessary, especially for a snack? This bar makes me think of the McDonald's Super Size idea. But, bigger is not necessarily better. A snack should not be so substantial high in calorie and fat content, unless you are about to go on a 8 mile hike or you are replacing an entire meal with this bar. As a snack, it is too much. I do not recommend as a regular snack.

Full nutritional info below:

Nutrition Facts - 1 bar - 220 calories, 12 grams of fat, 1.5 grams of saturated fat, 0 grams of trans fat, 3.5 grams of polyunsaturated fat, 6 grams of monounsaturated fat, 0 milligrams of cholesterol, 230 milligrams of sodium, 23 grams of carbohydrates, 3 grams of fiber, 13 grams of sugar, 7 grams of protein, 2% calcium, 100% vitamin E and 10% phosphorus.)

Ingredients: Peanuts, Corn Syrup, Sugar, Peanut Butter (Roasted Ground Peanuts), Crisped Rice (Rice Flour, Sugar, Malt Extract, Salt, Caramel Color, Mixed Tocopherols (to Help Protect Flavor)), Evaporated Cane Juice Invert Syrup, Whole Grain Rolled Oats, Fractionated Palm Kernel, Oil, Granola (Whole Grain Rolled Oats, Brown Sugar, Whole Grain Rolled Wheat, Coconut, Canola Oil, Wheat Bran), Partially Defatted Peanut Flour, Salt, fructose, Contains less than 1.5% of Sodium Caseinate (From Milk) Soy Lecithin, Resistant Corn Dextrin, Natural Flavor, Mixed Tocopherols (to help protect flavor).

Label: Neutral
Content: These bars were tasty, but extremely dense and heavy. I really had to chew! They are definitely filling, though, and taste pretty good. Probably a good breakfast for someone who needs fast protein and sugar.

Label: Neutral
Summary: These nut bars are making me thirsty!
Content: These nutty bars are huge compared to the average granola bar.  They actually taste pretty good too. They are definitely not a healthy type bar, more like a candy alternative.  The thing is covered with a peanut butter like coating on the bottom of the length of the bar which tastes great.  There are only 5 bars in the box, so I guess the large size is supposed to offset that.  I am a little on the fence, as they do taste good, but they aren't something I would normally crave for.  I do think they should be eaten with a drink nearby as they are a little on the dry side.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Not as great as they look
Content: Sure it sounds good and looks yummy on the box, but this is one mess of a "candy" bar. First of all, the peanut butter is all over the bottom (or is it the top?), so it forces you to use the wrapper or else. The flavor is a little more bland than I had expected as well. Overall, it wasn't bad, but I wouldn't rush out and buy any in the future.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Don't Forget to fix the Jug of Water While You Are At It..
Content:
If you choose to have this salty/sugary snack bar, which is basically a candy bar, fix yourself a jug of water, you will need it. I love Planters peanuts, but I prefer the old fashioned peanut bar, the real old fashioned one.

My question is this: Is it a granola bar, a nut bar, a candy bar, and I'm inclined to believe with the ingredients of 13 gms of fat, which is certainly not as much as some candy bars. Then, there is a layer of peanut butter spread on the bottom.

So, I don't think I would buy these if I had a hankering to fix the sweet tooth. For the healthy side, no; it's too sweet, too salty. ...Rizzo

Label: Neutral
Summary: Great tasting, but it's more of a meal than a snack...
Content:
I recently got a chance to try the new(ish) Planters Big Nut Bars from Kraft Foods and I have to say that they're pretty darn good. If you're into granola bars, these will be a little bit of a departure as you really don't get that kind of consistency. These are also nuttier, and overall seem to be more akin to a nut-based candy bar like a Payday.

As far as the pluses go, the bars have a nice balance of sweet and salty, and though the consistency doesn't scream granola bar, it's just chewy enough that it also doesn't scream peanut bar (like the various brands of peanut brittle-esqe bars you tend to find in vending machines.) The peanut butter coating on the bottom also has a nice consistency and taste, not chalky or too sweet like peanut butter tends to get in products like this. Also, at 46 grams, it's pretty satisfying, and I'd think it would certainly make for a decent small meal on the go if you're in a pinch.

There are some drawbacks though. Mainly the bars can get a little messy where the peanut butter is concerned, so I can imagine it would be a nightmare with kids. The bars are also pretty high in fat, which isn't as much surprising (they are peanut based), as it is unfortunate. At 13g of fat per bar (3g saturated), these really are in the category of meal replacement, and not snacks. If you're looking for a healthy snack I'd stick with a more basic granola bar.

Label: Neutral
Content: The taste of this product is very good.  It has that peanut buttery taste along with real peanuts for crunch.  The only thing is that it needs a bit more work.  1st of all, 220 calories!!!!  110 from fat!! Yikes.  For all you health nuts, this may not be the product for you.  2nd and most of all, you can't really eat this without getting your hands full of the peanut butter.  The bar is made up of nuts on the top with an underlayment of peanut butter on the bottom.  This means you can't eat the bar without the wrapper otherwise your fingers will melt the peanut butter and get all messy.  It would be better if the bar had the peanut butter "sandwiched" between two layers of peanuts.  Less mess and you won't need the wrapper.

Label: Neutral
Content:
The "big nut" bars from Planters peanuts are exactly as promised: extremely nutty. They remind me of Paydays, but without the chocolate covering and the intense sweetness.

Even though I love peanuts and PB, I'd probably only buy it if it were smaller or if the nuts were honey roasted...or if they had more than one flavor. They are a little too big for a mid-morning snack, and I'd definitely alternate this product with something else on a frequent basis.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Not Bad, But Definitely Not the Best
Content: Planters, of course, is the granddaddy of all peanut purveyors. They have been around forever and still put out the finest plain peanuts around. I would have thought that their forays into the niche market of nut bars would be more successful. Not so. These Big Nut Bars are tasty, quite good, but honestly cannot compare with such products as Nature Valley Sweet & Salty Nut Granola Bars, Peanut, 6-Count Boxes (Pack of 12), to name one. As I try to put my finger on the difference, I think it is this--the Planters product is just too big. If you want a lot of peanuts, this is for you. If, however, you want something a little smaller but with a more nuanced taste and palette, go with Nature Valley or one of the other competitors. Good luck next time, Planters.

Label: Neutral
Summary: An Example of Truth in Advertising
Content:
These things are definitely big, definitely have peanuts and peanut butter, and they're chewy. But they're also rather boring. You REALLY have to like peanuts to be able to work your way through one. It feels like something's missing -- a little sweetness, a little salt -- not sure what it is, but something would help. I asked the techs on my production crew to test a couple. Bear in mind that they'll eat anything from a craft service table, but they also found them lacking in some essential ingredient.

The bars also get a bit mushy to the point of being messy when warm.

If you're a big fan of peanuts and peanut butter and that's all you want, then these bars are for you. If you need a little variety in your treats, then maybe go for something with a little chocolate or other added flavors.

I'm sorry if I've hurt your feelings, Mr. Peanut. I've always been a big fan.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Not for diets, good on taste
Content: After receiving my box of Big Nuts bars from Amazon Vine, I eagerly tore into the box to get my first taste of this treat.  Expecting something more along the lines of a candy bar, I was pleasantly surprised by the taste: peanuty, definitely, with a slight sense of the granola bar that it is meant to imitate. They are not overpoweringly sweet, but the second and third ingredients in the label are sugar and corn syrup. At 220 calories a pop, they could easily be diet killers, including the 22 g of carbs each medium sized bar provides. Would I purchase these in the store? Probably not. Granola bars aren't my favorite thing. It was worth a taste, however.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Melt in heat, and not the healthiest
Content: Tasty, and healthier than candy bars, but a health bar it ain't (after peanuts, the next main ingredients are corn syrup and sugar).  The bars are currently a little over 50 cents a piece, which isn't bad for something to quench your hunger, which these little bars aren't too bad at.  That said, this deal is for about 5 lbs of peanut bars.  5 pounds of dry roasted, unsalted peanuts (which would be healthier than these bars) would only be a quarter of the price of these.  Maybe the convenience is worth it to you though.  Be aware that these bars do not do well in warm temperatures: the peanut butter they're smeared with gets melted very quickly.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Tastes decent, not very good for you
Content:
These are good, but I will not order these again. They taste like a payday granola bar, so good to substitute a candy bar, but not a good sub for a better snack or meal. They are a bit messy and have some ingredients I normally avoid: corn syrup and more salt than I prefer.

They are also very chewy; if you have complicated dental work, TMJ or issues with eating chewy foods -- you will want to steer clear of these.

Label: Neutral
Content: The peanuts were fine, but bland. The peanut butter was also bland.  Personally I could take it or leave it.  However, my girlfriend really liked them. She thought the combination of peanuts and peanut butter was great.  Calorie wise, they are average with a candy bar, and to be honest, I'd prefer a nutty candy bar with caramel.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Don't let words like "chewy granola bar" or "7 grams of protein" fool you into thinking that Planters Big Nut bars are any healthier than a candy bar.

Check out the ingredients:
(in order)
1)peanuts
2)corn syrup(a sweetner)
3)sugar
4)peanut butter(roasted ground peanuts)
5)crisped rice(rice flour, sugar, malt extract, salt, carmel color, mixed tocopherols)
6)evaporated cane juice invert syrup(a sweetner)
7)whole grain rolled oats
8)fractionated palm kernal oil
9)granola(whole grain rolled oats, brown sugar, whole grain rolled wheat,coconut, canolaoil, wheat bran)
10)partially defatted peanut flour
11)salt
12)fructose (a sweetner)
13)soy lecithin
14)resistant corn dextrin
15)natural flavor and mixed tocopherols

Thats a lot of sugar when you add it all up with each 46gram bar (which really isn't that big) weighing in with 220 calories, 110 calories from fat, 13grams of fat, 22grams of carbohydrate, 3grams of fiber, 12 grams of sugar and 7 grams of protein.

Inspite of all the sugar, I would have given a slightly better rating based on taste alone if I didn't get the impression Planters was trying to promote this product as something "healthy" instead of just another candy bar. Consumers already have a difficult enough time wading through all the hype when trying to make healthy choices at the supermarket!

Label: Neutral
Summary: Baraw Crow Bamas' Review: Planters Big Nut Bars
Content:
Are there healthier choices for a snack bar? Yes. Are there better tasting choices for a snack bar? Yes. Is there a snack bar with more of a peanut taste? Eh, maybe. I wanted to suggest these for when you go hiking. However, with 220 calories, and 110 of those being fat calories, I'm not so sure I would suggest these for hiking. Factor in the 160mg of sodium, it seems counter productive. Health wise, I would suggest countless other bars. Taste wise, I don't see these bars replacing Blueberry Trio Bars in our snack drawer. As for peanuty taste, it's a toss up between these and a Payday bar. I would give the edge to the Planters Big Nut Bars just on the healthier factor.

All in all, if you love peanuts, not worried about indulging, and don't mind a heavy feeling snack. Then by all means, this is a good choice for you.

Label: Neutral
Content:
You only get 5 bars in a box so the price comes out to almost .60 cents a bar, that's expensive. Especially when it's just a glorified PayDay candy bar. It does have 7g. of protein but also 22g. of carbs. so it's not a diet bar and it's not a low-carb bar. It also doesn't compare to a nut and granola bar, the granola in this bar looked like oats covered in a sugar glaze.

It tasted good on the start but by the finish it had a fake, burnt peanut taste, almost like rancid oil. Apparently my box had gotten too hot because the coating of peanut butter that is on the bottom of the bar had melted and it was a mess inside the wrapper. This would not be kid friendly in the car. It would be a great big mess.

I would pass on these for the cost and nutritional information alone. But then combined with the peanut butter coating on the bottom (!) it's definitely a no-go.

Label: Neutral
Content:
I'm a fan of Planters Big Nut Bars, Roasted Triple Nut, 8.1-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 10), so I was thinking these would be similar, only with all peanuts.

That wasn't the case...

These are more difficult to chew and more chewy than I like. They also have lots of sweetners included (in order): corn syrup, sugar, evaporated cane juice invert syrup, brown sugar (in granola), fructose to add up to 12g per bar. This is actually 1g less than the triple nut, so I'm not sure why I notice it more with these...

Overall, they are ok, but I wouldn't put them on my shopping list.

Label: Neutral
Content:
I have a sweet tooth or two and love chocolate....but despite that I found these cookies to be over-the-top sweet. (Sugar is the first ingredient on the package.) I will stick to a chocolate bar to satisfy my gluten-free chocolate cravings after these are gone.
If you plan to buy these, you may want to know that there are 9 cookies in each box. All of mine arrived broken and crumbled (not sure why since no previous problems with having food shipped to me by Amazon) but still taste good.

Label: Neutral
Content:
As a gluten-free chocoholic, I will say that these are the best mass-produced, gluten-free chocolate chocolate chip cookies I have found. The quality of the chocolate is very good -- a nice, rich, bittersweet flavor. The rest of the cookie, however, is disappointing. The cookies are very thick (more than 1/4"), dry, and brittle. That's rather surprising given their fat content: a whopping 9g per serving.

If you're a baker, you're better off making your own. But if you're not a baker and you love dark chocolate, these might be right up your alley.

Label: Neutral
Content: I really like these cookies. They are a chocoholic's dream. Just be aware if you order them when it's hot, get the fastest shipping you can or they melt inside their packages and make a tasty mess.

Label: Neutral
Content: These cookies would be better if the base dough recipe was the same as the Extreme Chocolate Mini Cookies with the addition of dark chocolate chunks.  As they are, they are more sweet than chocolate, and shouldn't in any way be considered a "dark" chocolate.  They aren't bad, they just aren't what is expected by the product description.  They also arrived more crumbled than intact, a problem classic in gluten-free baked goods that can be easily corrected by tweaking the recipe.  This is not one of this line's best offerings.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Tiny, sugary,  overpriced but taste good....
Content: Ultra tiny to be paying about $1 for a pack of 2.  Really not worth the price.  Sugary, somewhat crispy and very chocolaty but I was hoping for more melty chocolate pieces...disappointed in finding one or two per cookie.  Every cookie had part melted onto the wrapper or had one broken.  It was fun trying but way overpriced.  I won't repurchase.

Label: Neutral
Content: The cookies came crumbled into many pieces in 3 of the boxes I opened.  Also the chocolate chips had melted onto the cellophane.

Label: Neutral
Content: I was a little disappointed with this product. I am a big Pamela's Products fan, but these were just ok.

Label: Neutral
Summary: doenst work to reheat/defrost right in jar or glass container
Content: I think this machine is nice and the steam and blend cycle is nice but it takes an insignificant amount of extra time to dump food from basket directly into the blending container in the Beaba.  So as far as this difference I don't really think it is significant enough to go with the Brezza.  Beaba now makes a larger machine also.  I guess the cost is a little less for the Brezza but because of the disadvantage I am about to mention it absolutely does not work for me!  I chose the Beaba because you cannot put your jar or small glass container right into the Brezza to defrost or reheat like you can with the Beaba because of that middle rod that is part of the blades.  It is completely in the way in my opinion and they force you to use their plastic containers to store and reheat food!  I freeze my baby food in these tiny glass lock containers because I try to use glass when I can for storage.  I also buy the glass organic pre made baby food when I don't have time to cook as a backup and I need to be able to warm those since the baby doesn't eat the whole jar yet so I store left overs in the refrigerator.  You can put the jars and the glass containers directly in the Beaba basket to defrost and heat and I could not use the Brezza to do it.  I would have to defrost at room temp or in fridge then transfer to heat which takes way too long and I would have to transfer to the brezza containers which are plastic and then heat.  Not only this is completely time consuming (I do not use the microwave it irradiates your food, destroys nutrients and it is horrible!) it is also plastic and even though BPA free I am trying to avoid plastic like I mentioned so just steaming and blending in plastic is already too much for me so for storage I use glass only.  So this is a good machine but if you are looking for defrost/reheat function where you can put your own containers and jars into this machine will not work.

Label: Neutral
Content:
When I made baby food I liked to make massive quantities, freeze them in ice cube trays, and store them in Gallon storage bags. After using the Baby Brezza for a few months it stopped working. The company quickly sent me a replacement part, however during that time I realized it was much easier to just steam fruits and/ or veggies on the stove and process in a food processor. It was a much more efficient method.

The 'set it and forget it' motto is nice, however it cannot be used with every food. Most fruits (apples and pears for example) have to be drained after steaming and before processing. This means you can't just set it and foroget it. Certain vegetables (broccoli) require adding water prior to processing.

This product would probably be best for making smaller quantities and if you don't already have a food processor.

It also comes with great recipes which are all from (...)

Label: Neutral
Summary: Good product, but it broke after 2 months
Content:
I used the Baby Brezza for about 2 months and it broke. It was good while it lasted - very easy to use. A couple issues I did have with it -
1) It is difficult to remove the blender attachment. It seemed to be easiest to remove while hot but you have to be careful not to burn yourself in the process. Otherwise, it took a lot of force to pull out the attachment.
2) It broke after two months - it was the plastic part that helps to hold the middle rotor on the bottom. I didn't use this that often - probably 3-4 times every week since my baby just started solids and there were a few things I just mashed up instead of using the Baby Brezza.

I had intended to get this replaced through Baby Brezza but saw that it would cost $10 for me to ship it back to them - since this seemed like poor manufacturing on their part, I didn't want to pay to have it shipped back to them. I contacted Amazon and they provided me with a postage paid shipping and refunded the money very promptly.

I ended up buying a pressure cooker and using my food processor which seems to work just as well - it does mean using more pots/items which means a little bit more clean up but it's actually faster and I can make larger batches of food.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Update: Thanks to the wonderful folks at Lowe's they got the stripped screws out of the bottom of the item, and I purchased some new better quality screws to put back in it. Now that my item is fixed, I still will not give this product 5 stars, just because I do not think it is worth its cost. I think as easy as the belt comes on and off that is something that should be addressed whenever the company goes to make a newer model.

Received this off my wishlist for Christmas and was excited to use it, it steamed the veggies just fine, however it would not blend. The blade and its unit inside the baby food maker would not spin. I noticed other people on here have had the same problems. I tried to call the Baby Brezza company at 9:23 am EST since on their website it says their business hours are 9-5 EST. However their automated system would not let me speak to a customer service representative, you have to leave a message. Sorry, I want to talk to some one and NOT wait to be called back at YOUR convenience, but rather MINE. I gave them their chance, so I now have to wait to receive the Amazon invoice in the mail from my mother since she is the one who purchased it here on Amazon for me, and then I will be printing a FREE shipping label and returning with ease through Amazon. I was really looking forward to this baby food maker, however, I think I am going to be going with a different brand. This thing is a piece of crap. IT is so disappointing to try to make your baby food and to have this thing not work; on top of that, their customer service has disappointed me too.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Great...when it doesn't break! Good Customer service.
Content:
I got this baby food maker off of my baby registry. I wanted to make my baby's food so I knew what was going into his mouth. Well, it worked great the first few times and then the plastic broke off the bottom of the container that holds the metal pin in (holding in the blade.) I was able to rig it so that it still worked anyways. Then, a couple days later while making a batch of prunes, the motor went out! Well, surely this was designed to handle something a little thicker like prunes.

So, I called and emailed the baby brezza company. About a week later, they did call me and ended up sending me a brand new machine for no charge to me. But, in the meantime I steamed the food in my steamer and used my food processor. I loved that SO much more because I could do large batches. So, I think I may return the brezza. If you want to make food in tiny batches, this would be great. But, I found that a food processor and steamer are much more efficient for large amounts of food to freeze. So, 3 stars (being generous) for the machine and 5 stars for their customer service if it breaks :)

Label: Neutral
Summary: blade broken, then fixed, now works quite well
Content:
Received this as a Christmas present. Just like other reviewers noted, the item was never functional. The food was steamed, but the blade doesn't turn because the motor isn't engaging the turning knob. Not worth my time to fix a machine that never worked. Will get the Baby Cook instead.

OK, update on this product. I found a blog by searching for the product name in Google and something like "blade doesn't turn" and found a fix-it explanation that worked great. Another review on Amazon also has the way to fix this. So after taking 15 minutes to find a good fix, and 10 minutes of taking apart, fixing the band that connects the motor to the blade axis, and putting it back together, the Brezza works great. We have made all kinds of foods in the Brezza including carrots, apples, broccoli, pears, peas. All these items streamed well and pureed well too. However, we still do yams and squash in our immersion blender because the brezza seems to have a little trouble with those items.

I'd give it four stars but I took off one for the fact that I had to fix it upon arrival. I hope the company has indeed altered it's design to stop the bands from slipping off during shipping.

Label: Neutral
Content:
I have been using this device for the last three months. I feed my baby almost exclusively homemade foods (besides those my doctor recommends to buy in a jar), so I do use this quite a bit.

It is easy to use and it is convenient. My only complaint is the construction. Some of the materials seem a little cheap (for example, the button panel is starting to come off...it is just a sticker). I'm already having to buy another container because the plastic broke on my first one. I called the company to talk to them about it (because it seemed fishy to me that it would break so quickly under normal use, and there is supposedly a warranty) and I got a machine (during normal business hours). No one returned my call. I truly think that any company who makes things for people with babies need to have excellent customer service because their customers are sleep deprived and short on time. This company doesn't even come close to meeting a high standard. I'd rather pay the $25 for the replacement part than deal with the hassle.

So, basically, I like the device but I'm not crazy about the quality or customer service (the latter is basically non-existent at this point).

All this being said, I researched several other machines before buying this one. I'm not sure I would go back and buy a different device. At least I can buy replacement parts easily!

UPDATE: The replacement part didn't fit as it was a newer model than my machine. However, the customer service department did call me back and shipped me an entire new machine (newer model). Unfortunately, it still seems plauged with some problems. The drive shafts sometimes sticks and the buttons don't work very well. Ulimately, for me, not a worry-free machine.

Label: Neutral
Summary: frustrated but its a good product.
Content: A good product but I received one and the puree function didnt work sent it back and ordered another one. 2nd one had the same problem. I figured if two that I received had the same problem I must not be the only one.  I read reviews and saw that others were saying take the machine apart and put the black belt back on. We did that and now it works like a champ. Whatever the cause of the issue they need better quality control.

Label: Neutral
Content: Product was old. The chocolate was brittle, stale and easily sheared off from the jelly. Not the Jelly Rings I remember from childhood.

Label: Neutral
Content: As always Joyva is the BEST! My ONLY reason for not giving this a higher rating is the bottom layer was stale.  The rest was incredibly delicious!

Label: Neutral
Content: I purchased this as an option for my cat since he only eats chicken. This is a much drier and diced product (no juice) as compared to the other Whiskas products in a pouch. However, the pouch is quite stuff, so if you cat likes it, he will surely get enough to eat from this pouch. Also, the picture does not look like the product I was shipped.

Label: Neutral
Content:
We eat mostly gluten free as one of my kids has a sensitivity to it. While I try to bake all the goods myself, these looked like a good thing to carry as a snack when we travel. My daughter didn't like the cookie part much. SHe kept trying to pick out just the chocolate chips.

For myself, it was OK. Sometimes gluten free baked goods can have a grainy aftertaste and that was the case with these. The upshot was they make an excellent cookie crumb pie crust when you toss them in the food processor and grind them up.

Label: Neutral
Content: its nice to have them individually wrapped. the taste is ok but a little chemical taste in the parts without chocolate chunks. each individual would have to try for themselves. they will keep easily due to individual wrapping.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Can you say Wii are overrpriced?
Content: Another overpriced Wii product. Needs to be $1-$1.50 each not the 3.00 they cost me including shipping. Other than that, these are a great product. A bit too expensive for party favors which would be the proper target group.

Label: Neutral
Content: I believe that these were a great idea, however the flavors were not all that great, I couldn't even get my picky 3 year old to try them, my older daughter tried them and said that they were not that bad at first but started to taste icky after a while. I think if these were in regular flavors that it might have been an easier sell to my child.

Label: Neutral
Content: I agree with the other reviewers that kelp noodles are definitely a delicious and nutritious noodle substitute. But $10.95 is absolute ridiculously over priced. I live in Manhattan and buy the same product in H market in Korea Town for $2.99. I recommend this product, but not for this price. If you live in a metropolitan city I would suggest purchasing kelp noodles at any major Asian market for a fraction of the price listed here.

Label: Neutral
Content: I have looked everywhere for powdered milk that is not fat free and finally found it! Sent it to my cousin away at college and he says it's ok for the taste. Good for late night dorm snacks.

Label: Neutral
Summary: good taste but high sucrose content
Content:
The milk powder is very sweet and definitely not natural taste. High amount of sucrose added in,which lower the cost.(Sucrose is much cheaper than milk)

The taste is good though. For 12 dollars, it is not bad.

Label: Neutral
Content: I was about to make another purchase on this milk. I was going to do the monthly shipment. I'll never buy this again when it's cheaper elsewhere....It's a fantastic product, but too bad the price doubled like that..I just paid 13 for this....What happened??

Label: Neutral
Content:
this is a good product for people who like gum but have dental work to which most gum sticks.

I've ordered from Amazon because they have the best price for bulk purchases; I save almost 40% off per-pack retail prices.

There is potential for a problem; Wrigley dates each of its bulk packages with a best by date. Generally, Wrigley gum is 'fresh' if the best by date is 6 months or more in the future. Current shipments from Amazon are dated 5/9/09; this is only 2 months away. There is potential to receive stale product; Amazon would most likely accept a return but we don't buy things with the expectation we will return them.

Label: Neutral
Content: This would be great for someone who just wants to freshen their mouth for a few minutes. Would not recommend for those looking for long-lasting taste.

Label: Neutral
Content: Hi. I just wanted to point out two things about these chews. First of all, they are made in Mexico not the USA. Therefore, the ingredient list is misleading when it says "American" beef hide because it is meant to make you think that the beef hide is from the United States of America. More accurately, it should read, "North American" beef hide to distinquish it from being from Asia (note, the label does not specify the origin of the hydrolysed vegetable protein which could be wheat gluten). Secondly, these chews do not contain chlorhexidine like the "C.E.T" brand and this may be an ingredient you want if your dog has peridontal issues. My dogs like these chews and I think they do help to a small extent to clean the teeth. gb

Label: Neutral
Content: This is a high price for a two ounce tin of mint fragments.  The flavors are OK.  They are sweetened with xylitol which does not promote tooth decay and has some benefits as it supresses the growth of bacteria.  I guess you could call them small breath mints.  The small size tin can be carried in a purse, shoulder bag, or coat pocket (as long as you are not flying on an airplane).

Label: Neutral
Content: Although I love coconut oil and know of all the benficial ways to use it, this coconut oil tastes too coconutty for me.  I have to agree with other reviewers in that the smell is so strong it almost seems like an artificial scent. I dont mind coconut flavor and scents but this is almost too much.  It almost makes me gag.  I'll be going with Nutiva next time.

Label: Neutral
Content: The coconut oil arrived in good condition.  It had a stronger taste than conventional cooking oils that I did not care for.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Great. Who would pay $6.99 plus shipping for something that costs less than 50 cents?
Content: Great cheap soda. Worth every penny of the $.47 cents that it costs. Not worth $6.99 plus shipping.

Label: Neutral
Content: My dog loves the chicken, steak, and peanut butter booda bones, but he's not as fond of the spearmint/peppermint variety.  My dog will eat it if offered, but my dad's dog who I often sit for will not even touch these.  I wouldn't recommend for a dog who prefers meat.

Label: Neutral
Summary: OK, but the Golden Valley brand Organic is better
Content: I bought this product and the Golden Valley Natural Organic (Original) in order to compare them.  They're exactly the same price per ounce (the Golden Valley product is organic; the John Wayne organic is more expensive).  They're similar, both fall into the "soft" beef jerky category with no artificial ingredients.  However, the John Wayne product is a bit mealy and has a subtle but funny aftertaste.  This outweighs the single shortcoming of the Golden Valley product, which is that it is a bit too sweet.

Label: Neutral
Content: We heard this was the best stuff out there, Ordered and weren't all that excited. If you like a softer product this will be good, We ordered the teriyaki, good flavor odd texture. We are jerky fans, b ut won't order more of this, Our local guy gets our business.

Label: Neutral
Content:
These cookies come in super cute packaging- but what they have in looks they lack in filling! The cookies themselves are tasty but they could definitely step it up and add more filling inside of each one. I expected it to be jam packed with filling but it only had a little squeeze of it (imagine a pea size drop inside a quarter).
I would eat these again if I was starving...but it definitely would not be my first choice.

Label: Neutral
Content: Van Houtte coffee is one of my favorites but this medium roast has a little less kick to it than I had hoped.

Label: Neutral
Content: A nice mild coffee but not the best Colombian I have tasted.  Diedrich is still the better choice for me.  I don't think I would purchase this brand again.

Label: Neutral
Summary: quick easy not as tasty as my own recipe
Content: I love this companies flour and many of its products.  Pasta is great. Sauce not so much, for me. It is the color and strong taste.

Label: Neutral
Content: Knorr's comes the closest to resturaunt quality Hollandaise sauce. Aunt Penny's was okay, a little too much tanginess for my taste, not enough creamy butteriness. But, it's still better than making it myself and the store was out of Knorr's. I haven't tried Wagner's or Reese yet.

Label: Neutral
Content: This coffee smells so autumn, makes a pleasant cup of seasonal coffee, a little on the weak side, but good.

Label: Neutral
Summary: It would be great, if it wasn't for the poops
Content: I love the taste of these bars, but the poops always come within 30 minutes of eating just one.  It's not just poops, but crazy poops.  Still... I eat them, but I make sure I am alone at home and near a bathroom.  Those who aren't effected must have intestines of steel.  Co-workers and I were speaking about these bars this afternoon.  I'd asked if any of them had ever eaten them and, if so, what kind of side-effects resulted.  After all the embarrassed smiles and giggles, I didn't have to ask further.  Maybe they could reduce the fiber just a little?  Otherwise, the Chocolate Peanut Butter is the best.

Label: Neutral
Content:
The Good: Fiber One Bars taste great, are high in Fiber, and are a filling snack between meals

The Bad: Causes extreme gas, like nothing I have eaten before, and some minor stomach cramps.

Label: Neutral
Content:
The reviews of this extraordinary product pretty much cover the bases. Tasty? Check. Full of fiber? Check. Causes extreme gut pain? Check. Causes nonstop farting like you were born in New Jersey? HELL YEAH.

What can I add to this?

Well, a few months back my coworkers and I drew up a contract for a spirited competition. The contestants were to eat three bars back to back with plenty of fluid at breakfast. The winner would be determined by the last person to use the bathroom. Unfortunately during a test run where I consumed three bars in one sitting, I discovered that even tapping out and running at a full sprint to the bathroom was too much of a risk - especially at work! Thank GOD I was wearing my Ex Officio Give-N-Go Briefs! That at least contained the rush that I experienced.

We devised a different sport to compete in. Eat one bar and then 30 minutes later go to the gym and use the elliptical machine. You win in one of two ways: 1. Hold out and do not pass gas at all during a 20 minute workout. However you can also win by passing enough gas to drive your competitors off of their machines. So even if you tap out early you can still win.

It is critical to use the elliptical during this challenge due to the rapid cheek movement it causes.

I gotta stop eating these things. No one wants to sit near me anymore.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Any real peanuts in the bar?
Content: I just had my first bar drawn from our kitchen cupboard. It was the Oats and Peanut Butter bar.  I was attracted by the full-sized peanuts on the package photo.  About halfway through I realized that I hadn't yet tasted a peanut.  Even the peanut butter flavor was pretty weak.  Looking back at the package I realized that the photographer had placed full sized peanuts in the photo to make it LOOK like they were part of the bar.  Old time deceptive advertising.  You wouldn't think they'd need to do that still.  But then, we are easily fooled... aren't we?

Label: Neutral
Content: i love these bars! I was sad to find out that I spent almost 2x as much as I could have - the warehouse store had it for 9.99 for 30.

Label: Neutral
Content: Used to take to work for lunch. Tastes OK but is not real filling and a bit bland. Still a good idea for a quick meal.

Label: Neutral
Content: It adds a nice sweet flavor to my coffee.  I combine it with a little spoonable Stevita.  Better than Starbucks.  Its sweeting strength is a little weaker than I anticipated, but it will still last maybe 3 months because I combine it with the spoonable Stevita.  I iniatially used it without the spoonable stevita, but didn't like the taste.  Combining it is perfect.  For a 12oz. cup of coffee I use about 1/4 tsp. of spoonable Stevita and 7 drops of this van.liquid Stevita and some almondmilk for the cream.

Label: Neutral
Content:
I bought it as a substitute for powder Stevia hoping for better after-taste.
I am disappointed. The dropper design is faulty and I can't get drops in the coffee with out getting some on my fingers - an avoidable waste.
I also found that one needs to use more than a few drops to get the sweet taste.
The powder form is more economical if somebody makes half-packets of powder?

Label: Neutral
Content:
It is difficult to review food items because everyone has taste preferences that vary. I purchased this because I wanted some sort of sweetener for my coffee that would not affect my blood sugars. I found the flavoring to be a bit overpowering. I ended up using less than the recommended amount. I only use one drop in my coffee. I would suggest you start with one drop and then taste and adjust accordingly.

To me the vanilla flavor tastes artificial but you can't find any information on the label other that it contains "natural" flavoring.

But it does what it promises which is to sweeten and flavor. It will also last for a long time since only drops are used.

Label: Neutral
Content:
Maybe my expectations were too high. Heeding the warnings about adding too much I started with 8 oz of bottled seltzer and added a few drops. The taste was more of a hint than a true flavoring so I added a little more, figuring if I got the taste I liked I'd start from scratch and get a better measurement. It never happened for me. When I added enough to create some flavor I also found an aftertaste that was somewhat alcohol-y. Not a problem for most people but I strongly dislike the taste of alcohol so it's not good for me. Played with it some more and never got a satisfactory result. Into the fridge, back of the shelf.

A couple of weeks later I came home with some diet orange soda. Thought I'd try it again and see if I could make some orange cream soda and voila! Delicious. I say this having only tried one 8 oz serving and I made it a little too sweet but I have no doubt that once I get the ratio correct I'll add this to any orange soda I drink from now on. I'll probably try it with other flavors too altho orange seems to be the sure thing.

Label: Neutral
Content: I have tried the vanilla on cereal, in a smoothie and I don't really like the flavor.  It seems too bland to me.  I don't know that I would purchase it again.  I think it is a matter of what a person likes.  I have never liked Vanilla  ice cream either so that is probably just me.

Label: Neutral
Content: I purchased liquid stevia in an effort to use more natural sugars in my baking. I tried simply replacing white sugar with liquid stevia in my favorite recipes. I went to Sweet Leaf's website and used their conversion chart. I found that 1 tsp of liquid stevia for every 1 cup of sugar was too much. The intial taste was ok but had a strong aftertaste that stayed in your mouth for awhile. I later tried recipes specifically calling for liquid stevia. These recipes tasted quite good and typically used less liquid stevia.

Label: Neutral
Content: I had read other reviews on this product and really was looking forward to trying them. I have to say I was alittle disappointed they are really just ok to me nothing fantastic.

Label: Neutral
Content: I've used liquid stevia for over 5 years and have used 2 brands. I like the Sweet Leaf brand the most and have had the most experience with that brand.  When Sweet Leaf liquid stevia is new, it is a perfectly clear liquid.  Although I'm not sure why, when it ages, it turns a caramely brown color although it retains its taste and effectivness.  I purchased the Vanilla Creme (my favorite in plain Greek yogurt) on Amazon to save time in running to our health food store 40 minutes away.  The transaction was great and shipping was fast.  However, when I opened them, they were already caramely brown, which indicates to me that their stock is old, which is why I gave the review only 3 stars.  Although everything else was just fine, I think I will stick to getting it from my health food store to ensure the highest freshness (because it lasts such a long time anyway).

Label: Neutral
Summary: Didn't taste as good as I expected
Content: I needed some sugar-free sweetner for my coffee and I wanted it to be flavored. I was hoping that this product would meet that need but I was a little disappointed in how much after-taste there was. I still use it but not as much as I would if it tasted better.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Good in moderation, but can be bitter
Content: This is by far (in my opinion) the best flavor of the Sweet Leaf line. The Vanilla is versatile and can be used for cooking, coffee, tea etc. The ONLY problem I have with the drops is it can be very hard to figure out exactly how much you need for something. I think a HUGE improvement to the product would be to have measuring lines on the dropper. Otherwise, you spend all this time counting out the drops because if you go OVERLY sweet.. bleck.. bitter city.

Label: Neutral
Content:
I use this stuff pretty much anywhere--coffee, tea, plain water, oatmeal, you name it. It's tasty and cost-efficient.

My one complaint is that, more than a few drops, and you get a really noticeable aftertaste, kinda like alcohol or something burnt. This stinks because I occasionally like to make really sweet coffee for dessert, but the aftertaste is horribly distracting.

Label: Neutral
Content: My German shepherd (mix) has ear problems, right around this time of year he developers ear wax problems build up. I wash his ears constantly, but still the bacteria seem to re-grow and developed ear infection.

Label: Neutral
Content: Got this hoping to cut back on my creamer/Splenda consumption for sweetness! It does sweeten, you can add as little or as much as you want with the dropper. It does taste ok, although you do NOT get a big vanilla flavor with it, but that is ok too. My only problem, it does leave an aftertaste. Maybe it is me because I am so used to my creamers, but I had my daughter try it and she had one too. I guess I will stick to my creamer/Splenda for now. Would love to retry if they can work on the aftertaste problem.

Label: Neutral
Content: It took about 8 drops for coffe and 16 for green tea (green tea has a bad taste anyways, so its not the stevia's fault). The vanilla scent was really nice and relaxing. I'd choose this better than the unflavored stevia.

Label: Neutral
Content: I have just recently discovered Stevia (in powder), then I tried the liquid, then I tried this flavor.  I have to say this is pretty good...but I like the flavorless liquid better.  I havent used it to bake or sweeten any foods, but I can give it high praise in coffee & tea.

Label: Neutral
Content: I love the Sweet Leaf stevia, but the Vanilla Creme isn't one of my favorites. It's an odd flavor and doesn't taste very vanilla-y to me. If you are new to Sweet Leaf, I recommend trying a different flavor: my favorites are Rootbeer, English Toffee, and Cinnamon.

Label: Neutral
Summary: This particular product is decent when mixed with other fruits!
Content: Not as sweet fruits work the best for me when making smoothies using this product. I usually blend protein with this stuff with water and blueberries. If you're looking to really make a healthy drink try mixing in a tablespoon of Green Vibrance with each smoothy.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Better than liquid color - not as good as paste
Content:
I've used liquid and paste color in the past and this product seems to be somewhere in between. I had to use quite a bit of the substance to achieve the color I was looking for. In paste colors, you get a dramatic result with just a drop. The Ateco are quite a bit better than the liquid color, and, for the price, it's probably about right.

The bottom line - You get what you pay for. If you want dramatic colors, you can achieve that using a good portion of the bottle. If you want subtle colors, this may be what you're looking for.

Label: Neutral
Content: I purchased these colors to replace the Wilton gel colors, many of which I find give my icing an off taste.  These do not affect the taste of my icing, so get stars for that.  But, while they are stronger in hue than the cheap, liquid colors, they are not nearly as intense as the gel colors.  I had to add quite a bit of red and blue to acheive purple, and even then, it wasn't a very vibrant shade.  I would recommend simply due to the taste issue, however.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Not good for Easter egg coloring
Content: I bought this set because my niece was obsessed with having a black Easter egg (kids!) long story short, even though I used an entire bottle the coloring of the eggs were not vibrant. Not sure how they would work for baking so that's why they are still getting 3 stars.

Label: Neutral
Summary: This is the same product as Americolor,apparently
Content: I just bought this set and I have not had the chance to try it, though I'm looking forward to it.  However, I just wanted to note that to my surprise, one of the dyes actually had the "AmeriColor" label on it, which I thought was a completely different brand of food coloring.  It was leaf green from AmeriColor rather than green from Ateco.  Furthermore, the bottles were all completely identical between the Americolor and other Ateco bottles in the bo.  I don't know if maybe they just remove the labels from AmeriColor bottles and add Ateco labels?  At any rate, you can save a few bucks by buying the cheaper AmeriColor since I think it's pretty clear that they are the same thing...

Label: Neutral
Content: I am an avid macaron baker (the French macarons not the American ones.) I've had some problems with the yellow messing up my shell batter.  I feel like the color is not as intense, therefore I have to use more of it to get the desired color.  I'd been using the limited range of powdered colors that I have, and thought that switching over to the gel stuff would be okay but it has been troublesome for me.  Regardless, the colors (save yellow) are bright and vibrant.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Don't use to color white chocolate or candy coating
Content: I bought these to color the coating I use for cake pops. With either melted white chocolate or the Wilton Candy Melts, both seized up when I added the gel coloring. I was able to get pastel colors okay without seizing but when I tried for a more vibrant look, it clumped so badly, I couldn't use it. The product is fine used for frostings or icings though.

Label: Neutral
Content: I got these today, and though I cannot comment on their performance, I should note that instead of getting a bottle of black which was supposed to be in the set, I got two bottles of brown. Brown is a color I rarely use so this is quite disappointing.

Label: Neutral
Content: This food coloring kit sounds great except that they do not give the ounce sizes of the bottles.  What's up with that?  It would be nice to know how much product you are getting for your dollar.

Label: Neutral
Content: Frankly, the flavor is nothing special.  There is no overtone of any Kahlua influence.  Dom Francisco vanilla nut, and hazelnut are just as good, if not better, at half the price.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Good coffee but flavor was barely noticeable
Content: Given all the 5-star reviews and feedback, I was expecting a strong hazelnut flavor.  However, the hazelnut flavor was barely noticeable to me, although I was generous with the ground. Nevertheless, there was a hint of non-alcoholic Kahlua to it and the coffee tasted smooth.

Label: Neutral
Content:
The powder is really fine, so it mixes into baking nicely. I use it with regular milk in pumpkin pie (instead of condensed milk) and the pie is just as tasty. But, when trying to mix it into liquid to drink I couldn't get it smooth, even when I used a whisk. I put it through a fine sieve (which is more work than justified) and even that didn't entirely smooth it out.

Good for baking as a dry ingredient, not so much for drinking.

Label: Neutral
Summary: No ingredients listed - very high sugar %
Content: There was no ingredients listed for this product so I purchased anyway thinking all Instant Milk is basically the same, wrong: This stuff was hard to mix and must have been 25% sugar. I ended up giving all 4 pounds I purchased away, seller would never respond to my request of an ingredients list.

Label: Neutral
Summary: Diet Mt. Dew - if you want diet go elsewhere.
Content: Mt. Dew is a fabulous beverage. A fine morning pick-me-up, or a way to stretch the day.  A diet beverage, however, it is not.  Stick w/ the real thing.  The taste is reminiscent of regular Mt. Dew, but it's a tease.

Label: Neutral
Content: We love Eclipse mints, but the Spearmint flavor is too spicy for my family (tastes more like a peppermint).  We prefer the Winterfrost- it's minty but milder than the Spearmint.

Label: Neutral
Content:
I took in a foster cat almost one year ago and have tried almost everything to rid him of diarrhea. The vets were unable to diagnose any parasite or physical problems, and his behavior has always appeared happy and healthy. The vets said it could be a food allergy, so I began trying different foods. A couple of months ago, I bought SD Sensitive Stomach. I had been reluctant because of the ingredients - I strive to avoid foods with "meal" of any kind - as well as the price ($40 for 15.5 lbs). After a year, five other foods and several supplements, though, I was desperate. Sensitive Stomach did the trick. There was a noticeable difference within a few weeks, and the stools are completely normal now. His weight gain has been constant regardless of food, so I do not attribute that to the Science Diet brand.
